subject: History
note: Content vehicles for KS2 History. Seeded from Topics layer + v4 teacher feedback (Adeyemi). Each vehicle is a teaching pack for a statutory or optional topic study.

vehicles.name: Stone Age to Iron Age Britain
vehicles.description: Changes in Britain from the Stone Age to the Iron Age, covering hunter-gatherers to early farming, Bronze Age technology, and Iron Age hill forts.
key_events: Introduction of bronze tools c.2500 BC
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils place the three ages (Stone, Bronze, Iron) in chronological order and explain what changed between them? Can they use archaeological evidence (e.g. Skara Brae) to make inferences about daily life? Can they explain the SIGNIFICANCE of farming as a turning point?
success_criteria: Sequence Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age on a timeline
Explain at least 2 changes between the periods (e.g. tools, settlement, farming)
Use an archaeological source to make an inference about daily life
Explain why the development of farming was significant

vehicles.name: Roman Britain
vehicles.description: The Roman Empire and its impact on Britain, from invasion (43 AD) through occupation to withdrawal (410 AD). Covers Romanisation, resistance, and legacy.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain WHY the Romans invaded (multiple causes: trade, resources, prestige)? Can they use a primary source (e.g. Vindolanda tablet) to make inferences about Roman life? Can they assess the SIGNIFICANCE of the Roman legacy in modern Britain?
success_criteria: Sequence key events of Roman Britain chronologically
Explain at least 2 causes of the Roman invasion
Use a primary source to make an evidence-based inference
Assess the significance of one aspect of Roman legacy

vehicles.name: Anglo-Saxon and Scots Settlement
vehicles.description: Britain's settlement by Anglo-Saxons and Scots after Roman withdrawal, covering migration, kingdoms, conversion to Christianity, and cultural legacy.
sources: Sutton Hoo helmet and grave goods
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain WHY the Anglo-Saxons came to Britain and what happened to the existing population? Can they use the Sutton Hoo finds to make inferences about Anglo-Saxon society? Can they assess the SIGNIFICANCE of Christianity's arrival?
success_criteria: Explain reasons for Anglo-Saxon migration to Britain
Describe at least 2 features of Anglo-Saxon life using evidence
Use the Sutton Hoo finds to make an inference about status and belief
Assess the significance of one aspect of Anglo-Saxon legacy

vehicles.name: Vikings and Anglo-Saxon England
vehicles.description: The Viking and Anglo-Saxon struggle for the Kingdom of England to the time of Edward the Confessor, covering raids, Danelaw, and unification.
key_events: Alfred defeats Vikings at Edington 878 AD
Cnut becomes King of England 1016 AD
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain the CAUSES of Viking raids and settlement? Can they describe the consequences of the Danelaw agreement? Can they use sources to evaluate whether Vikings were raiders or settlers?
success_criteria: Explain causes and consequences of Viking raids on Britain
Describe the Danelaw and its significance
Compare Viking and Anglo-Saxon perspectives using sources
Sequence key events from Lindisfarne to Edward the Confessor

vehicles.name: Local History Study
vehicles.description: A study of an aspect of local history, using local sites, buildings, and sources. Adaptable to any locality — focuses on historical skills through familiar places.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils use local primary sources (census, maps, photographs) to find out about the past? Can they explain how their locality has changed and suggest reasons why? Can they assess the significance of a local person, event, or building?
success_criteria: Use at least 2 local primary sources to find information about the past
Explain how the local area has changed over time with evidence
Ask and answer historical questions about local places
Present findings about local history clearly

vehicles.name: British History Beyond 1066
vehicles.description: A study of an aspect or theme in British history that extends knowledge beyond 1066. Flexible choice — could cover Tudors, Victorians, World Wars, or other post-1066 themes.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe and explain the chosen aspect/theme? Can they identify causes and consequences of key events? Can they use sources from the chosen period to support their arguments?
success_criteria: Describe the chosen theme or aspect with accurate historical detail
Explain causes and consequences of at least 2 key events
Use period-appropriate sources to support an argument
Make connections to broader British history

vehicles.name: Ancient Sumer
vehicles.description: The achievements of the earliest civilisation in Mesopotamia — invention of writing, city-states, law codes, and irrigation.
key_events: Development of cuneiform writing c.3400 BC
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain what makes Sumer a 'civilisation' (writing, cities, laws, religion)? Can they identify the SIGNIFICANCE of Sumerian inventions (especially writing)? Can they use a source (e.g. Standard of Ur) to make inferences about Sumerian society?
success_criteria: Explain at least 3 features that made Sumer a civilisation
Describe the significance of the invention of writing
Use a Sumerian source to make an evidence-based inference
Compare Sumer with another ancient civilisation

vehicles.name: Ancient Egypt
vehicles.description: Ancient Egyptian civilisation — pyramids, pharaohs, hieroglyphs, mummification, and the River Nile's role in sustaining civilisation.
key_events: Unification of Upper and Lower Egypt c.3100 BC
Building of Great Pyramid c.2560 BC
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how the Nile CAUSED Egyptian civilisation to develop? Can they use an Egyptian source (e.g. tomb painting) to make inferences? Can they assess the SIGNIFICANCE of a discovery (e.g. Rosetta Stone, Tutankhamun's tomb)?
success_criteria: Explain the role of the Nile in Egyptian civilisation
Describe at least 3 achievements of Ancient Egypt
Use an Egyptian source to make an evidence-based inference
Assess the significance of one Egyptian discovery or achievement

vehicles.name: The Shang Dynasty
vehicles.description: The Shang Dynasty of Ancient China — oracle bones, bronze casting, writing system, and social hierarchy.
key_events: Founding of Shang Dynasty c.1600 BC
Fall of Shang Dynasty c.1046 BC
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain what oracle bones tell us about Shang beliefs and society? Can they describe the SIGNIFICANCE of Shang bronze technology? Can they compare the Shang Dynasty with another ancient civilisation?
success_criteria: Describe at least 3 features of Shang Dynasty civilisation
Explain what oracle bones reveal about Shang beliefs
Assess the significance of Shang bronze casting
Compare the Shang Dynasty with one other ancient civilisation

vehicles.name: Ancient Greece
vehicles.description: Ancient Greek civilisation — democracy, philosophy, Olympics, myths, and the legacy of Greek ideas in the modern world.
key_events: Golden Age of Athens c.461-429 BC
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how Athenian democracy worked and who was excluded? Can they assess the SIGNIFICANCE of Greek legacy (democracy, philosophy, Olympics)? Can they use Greek sources to compare life in Athens and Sparta?
success_criteria: Describe how Athenian democracy worked
Explain at least 2 ways Greek ideas influence the modern world
Compare life in Athens and Sparta using evidence
Assess the significance of one Greek achievement

vehicles.name: Early Islamic Civilisation
vehicles.description: A non-European society — the early Islamic civilisation including a study of Baghdad c.900 CE. Covers scholarship, trade, architecture, and cultural achievements.
key_events: House of Wisdom established c.800 CE
Golden Age of Islamic scholarship c.800-1200 CE
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain WHY Baghdad became a centre of learning (trade, patronage, translation)? Can they describe the SIGNIFICANCE of Islamic contributions to science, mathematics, and medicine? Can they use a source to make inferences about life in Baghdad c.900 CE?
success_criteria: Explain why Baghdad became a centre of learning
Describe at least 3 achievements of early Islamic civilisation
Use a source to make an inference about life in Baghdad
Assess the significance of Islamic contributions to modern knowledge

vehicles.name: Benin (West Africa)
vehicles.description: A non-European society — the Kingdom of Benin (West Africa) c.900-1300 CE. Covers the Oba, Benin Bronzes, trade, and the kingdom's achievements.
key_events: Founding of Benin Kingdom c.900 CE
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe the achievements of the Kingdom of Benin using the Bronzes as evidence? Can they explain the SIGNIFICANCE of the Benin Bronzes as both art and historical source? Can they discuss different PERSPECTIVES on the Bronzes (including repatriation debates)?
success_criteria: Describe at least 3 features of the Kingdom of Benin
Use a Benin Bronze to make an inference about Benin society
Explain why the Benin Bronzes are historically significant
Discuss different perspectives on the Bronzes
